presenter.bio: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management

slide.title: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management
slide.titleNormalized: eus for portal hypertension and varix management
slide.notes: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is emerging as a useful diagnostic and therapeutic tool for the evaluation and management of gastroesophageal varices
slide.notesNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound (eus) is emerging as a useful diagnostic and therapeutic tool for the evaluation and management of gastroesophageal varices
slide.notesHtml: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is emerging as a useful diagnostic and therapeutic tool for the evaluation and management of gastroesophageal varices
slide.text: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management THAWEE Ratanachu-EK, MD Digestive Endoscopy Center Rajavithi Hospital, Bangkok, THAILAND EUS Summit 2018, 6-7 October, AMC, Seoul, Korea

slide.text: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management PHT: Varices and Collateral pathways Role of EUS Immerging new intervention

slide.title: Portal Hypertension: Variceal Bleeding
slide.notes: Variceal bleeding is one of the most serious event and cause of death in patients with portal hypertension.
slide.notesNormalized: variceal bleeding is one of the most serious event and cause of death in patients with portal hypertension.
slide.notesHtml: Variceal bleeding is one of the most serious event and cause of death in patients with portal hypertension.

slide.title: Clinical management of acute variceal bleeding
slide.titleNormalized: clinical management of acute variceal bleeding
slide.notes: More than a decade, The efficient multi-step management of active bleeding have significantly improved the outcomes. Endoscopy plays the important role both diagnosis and treatment.
slide.notesNormalized: more than a decade, the efficient multi-step management of active bleeding have significantly improved the outcomes. endoscopy plays the important role both diagnosis and treatment.
slide.notesHtml: More than a decade, The efficient multi-step management of active bleeding have significantly improved the outcomes. Endoscopy plays the important role both diagnosis and treatment.
slide.text:
de Franchis R. J Hepatol 2015;63:743-752
Clinical management of acute variceal bleeding Suspected variceal bleeding Resuscitation/ICU, antibiotic, blood component,… Early vasoactive drug administration (Somatostation/Octreotide/Trelipresssin) Endoscopy (Diagnosis/Therapeutic) Control active bleeding (Banding,EIS-EV/Glue-GV) Re-bleeding Schedule for endoscopic eradication Rescued with BRTO, TIPS/Surgery Optional: SEMS* (EV) Balloon intubation* (SB for EV, Linton-Nachlas for GV) Hemospray* (EV,GV)
X * only for temporary therapy Garcia-Tsao G, et al. Am J Gastroenterol 2007;102:2086–2102 Ibrahim M, et al. United European Gastroenterology Journal 2015,3:277–283

slide.title: EGVs: Diagnostic EGD
slide.text: EGVs: Diagnostic EGD White nipple sign RWM: Cherry red spots,CRS Hematocystic spots Index bleeder Predicted bleeding risk

slide.title: Esophago-gastric varices: Endotherapy
slide.notes: Endoscopy is the important modalities treatment for EGVs, such as endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS), endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) mainly for EV and cyanoacrylate glue (CYA) injection for GV under conventional endoscopy.
slide.notesNormalized: endoscopy is the important modalities treatment for egvs, such as endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (eis), endoscopic variceal ligation (evl) mainly for ev and cyanoacrylate glue (cya) injection for gv under conventional endoscopy.
slide.notesHtml: Endoscopy is the important modalities treatment for EGVs, such as endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS), endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) mainly for EV and cyanoacrylate glue (CYA) injection for GV under conventional endoscopy.
slide.text:
Esophago-gastric varices: Endotherapy Esophageal varices Gastric varices Primary prophylaxis Banding Control bleeding Banding Injection sclerotherapy optional: Glue injection#/SB intubation* Secondary prophylaxis Banding Injection sclerotherapy
Primary prophylaxis Questionable# Control bleeding Glue injection (GOV1/2,IGV) Sclerotherapy/BRTO Banding (GOV1) optional: SB intubation (GOV1)# Secondary prophylaxis Glue injection
TIPS (IR)/ Surgery * only for briding therapy # for rescue therapy/post band induced ulcer bleeding # Garcia-Pagan JC, et al.CGH2014;12:919-928

slide.title: EGVs: Improved outcome?
slide.notes: Although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20% and serious embolism from glue injection.
slide.notesNormalized: although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20% and serious embolism from glue injection.
slide.notesHtml: Although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20% and serious embolism from glue injection.
slide.text:
EGVs: Improved outcome? Esophageal varices Gastric varices (GOV2/IGV1) Initial hemostasis: 83%-100% Re-bleeding: 8%-18% Embolism 2.1%
MARTINEZ-GONZALEZ J, et al. Rev. esp. enferm. dig. [online]. 2015,107, pp.501-508. Cipolletta L, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 1998; 47:400-3 Lee MS, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2002; 56:83-8. Al-Bawardy B, et al. J Clin gastroenterol 2016;50:4580462 Initial hemostasis:> 90% Un-controlled*/ Re-bleeding: 10-20% Stricture (EIS) 11%
*An elevated HVPG >20 mmHg (measured within 24 hours of presentation) Garcia-Tsao G, et al. Am J Gastroenterol 2007;102:2086–2102 EVL>EIS Glue

slide.title: Varices & Collateral pathways
slide.notes: Back to understand the collateral pathway of varices formation that is very important for varices management in term of how to decrease rebleeding the mortality or even control in active bleeding.

slide.title: Varices & Collateral pathways: GV
slide.text: drawing picture by Dr.Tanyaporn Chantarojanasiri Mehta G, Abraldes JG, Bosch J. Gut 2010;59:701-705. Charbel YAZBECK, MD. NDS University Hospital, USEK EV GOV1 LGV PV SV IGV2 RV SMV GOV2/IGV1 LGV PGV SGV GRS Varices & Collateral pathways: GV

slide.title: EUS for EGVs: Do more
slide.text: EUS for EGVs: Do more Diagnosis* Visualization and evaluation of EGVs (peri-,paravariceal, perforating v, LGVs Visualize of portal and azygos system Flow direction (inflow vs out flow) Measured portal pressure gradient (PPG) and measure vein cut surface area (CSA) by digitalized image *Wang A-J, et al. Endoscopic Ultrasound. 2016;5:218-224. Huang JY, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2017;85:996-1001

slide.title: Endoscopic Ultrasound-Guided Portal Pressure Measurement
slide.notes: Ken chang group demonstrated feasibility of eus guide technique to measure PPG and they found excellent correlation with some clinical parameter of PH.
slide.notesNormalized: ken chang group demonstrated feasibility of eus guide technique to measure ppg and they found excellent correlation with some clinical parameter of ph.
slide.notesHtml: Ken chang group demonstrated feasibility of eus guide technique to measure PPG and they found excellent correlation with some clinical parameter of PH.
slide.text:
Endoscopic Ultrasound-Guided Portal Pressure Measurement Huang JY, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2017;85:996-1001 PPG measurement (PPGM) accurately reflects the degree of PH
Target: Portal vein and Hepatic vein (or inferior vena cava) (via transgastric/transduodenal)
First human trial: 28 patients underwent EUS-PPGM with 100% technical success and no complications.
PPG ranged from 1.5–19mmHg and had excellent correlation with clinical parameters of PH : presence of varices (p=0.0002), : PH gastropathy (p=0.007) : thrombocytopenia (p=0.036) : cirrhosis (p=0.005). Compact manometer

slide.title: EUS for EGVs: Use more
slide.notes: what’s benefit for seeing more, number 1, number 2 and more impostantly number 3
slide.notesNormalized: what’s benefit for seeing more, number 1, number 2 and more impostantly number 3

slide.text: EUS for EGVs: Use more Management Predict risk of bleeding, recurrence, re-bleeding Assessment of pharmacological effect of drugs on PH Predictor outcomes of EGVs EUS guided therapy: sclerotherapy/ glue/ coil /,… Intrahepatic portosystemic shunt Wang A-J, et al. Endoscopic Ultrasound. 2016;5:218-224. “Clinical application”

slide.title: EUS for EGVs: See more, more prediction
slide.titleNormalized: eus for egvs: see more, more prediction
slide.text:
EUS for EGVs: See more, more prediction Predict risk of variceal rupture
Faigel DO, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2000; 52:455-62. 97% prior bleeding (+ Paraesophageal varices) vs 3% in control (OR3.1) Miller L, et al. Am J Gastroenterol. 2003; 98:454-9. Measure variceal cut surface area (CSA) by digitalized image: 76 fold increase: Sq.cm Predict risk of re-bleeding
Severe periesophageal collateral veins and large perforating veins. Predict risk of recurrence Irisawa A, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2001; 53:77-84. Sato T, et al. Hepatol Res. 2009; 39:126-33. Perforating veins: inflowing direction and more cardia intramural veins. Hino S, et al. Endoscopy. 2001; 33:869-72. LGV: High hepatofugal flow (>12 cm/s), dominance of anterior branch Kuramochi A, Hino S, Gastroenterol. 2007; 42:219-24 Irisawa A, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 1999; 50:374-380. Main ref. Wang A-J, et al. Endoscopic Ultrasound. 2016;5:218-224. EV

slide.title: EUS for EGVs: See more, treat more
slide.titleNormalized: eus for egvs: see more, treat more
slide.text:
Efficacy of pharmacotherapy Liao WC, et al. J Gastroenterol. 2015; 50:342-9. EUS for EGVs: See more, treat more Measure: Azygos blood flow A marked decrease after 1, 5, and 10 min bolus injections of terlipressin and somatostatin. Lee YT, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 1999; 50:47-52. : Volumetric change of paraesophageal varices (related with risk of recurrence) Guided therapy Lahoti S, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2000;51:331-333 de Paulo GA, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2006; 63:396-402.
Targeting the perforating veins (EV): Good result and less recurrence EV

slide.title: Gastric varices: Endotherapy
slide.notes: Although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20% Residual patency of treated varices correlated with risk of rebleeding after glue injection. Varix obliteration was also confirmed by the absence of blood flow on color Doppler.
slide.notesNormalized: although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20% residual patency of treated varices correlated with risk of rebleeding after glue injection. varix obliteration was also confirmed by the absence of blood flow on color doppler.
slide.notesHtml:
Although well control active bleeding, anyway let still a certain number of uncontrolled and recurrent bleeding 10-20%

Residual patency of treated varices correlated with risk of rebleeding after glue injection. Varix obliteration was also confirmed by the absence of blood flow on color Doppler.
slide.text:
Gastric Fundal Varices (GOV2/IGV1) Initial hemostasis: 83%-100% Re-bleeding: 8%-18% Embolism 0.5-4.3% Post injection ulcer, scope damage Fetal: case report* from cerebral and splenic embolization
Glue injection Gastric varices: Endotherapy Saraswat VA, Verma A. J Clin Exp Hepatol. 2012;2:55–69. *Ashraf P, et al. J Coll Physicians Surg Pak. 2011;21:574–576 *Martins Santos MM, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2007;65:1088–1090.

slide.title: GVs: EUS guided therapy
slide.text:
Romero-Castro R, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2007;66:402-7 Romero-Castro R, et al. Endoscopy 2010;42:;:E35-36 GVs: EUS guided therapy GV: EUS guided injection GV: EUS guided coil deployment N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate (Histoacryl) 2-octyl-cyanoacrylate (Dermabond) Sclerosant Glue
Others: thrombin,… Levy MJ, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2008;67:572-574 Irisawa A. APDW 2015

slide.title: EUS-guided GVs: Glue
slide.text:
EUS-guided GVs: Glue Objective: to assess the efficacy 5 cases (2005-2006) Cyanoacrylate-Lipiodol with 22G EUS needle Target: perforating feeder veins (GV) Result: successful GV eradication with less glue and no recurrent
Romero-Castro R, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2007; 66:402-7.

slide.title: GVs: EUS guided coil deployment
slide.notes: Metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation
slide.notesNormalized: metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation
slide.notesHtml: Metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation

slide.title: GVs: EUS guided coil deployment
slide.notes: Metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation
slide.notesNormalized: metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation
slide.notesHtml: Metal coils are covered with synthetic thrombotic material to promote clot aggregation

slide.title: EUS-guided GVs: Coil vs Glue
slide.text:
EUS-guided GVs: Coil vs Glue Romero-Castro R, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2013;78:711-721 Retrospective analysis of a prospective maintained database, multicenter study 11 patients: coil group vs 19 patients CYA group Inclusion criteria: bleeding GV, ASAI-III, Exclusion: disfuse GV, Plt<50,000, INR>2, SV thrombosis, Esophageal-stricture Under Propofol, Antibiotic, Ambulatory care, F/U Wk1-Month6 Approach: Trans-esophageal or trans-gastric Technique: Coil-stainless steel synthetic fibered coil(MREYE, IMWCE (Cook), diameter 8-20mm; straight length of 50-150 mm, 3.2-5.6 configuration loops a mean of 5.8+/-1.2 coils (2-13) per patient
CYA- a mixture of N-bytyl-2-cyanoacrylate with lipiodol (1:1) 1ml/portion at perforating vein with 22G needle a mean 1.5+/- 0.1 ml (1-3) CYA use Vessel thrombosis: : Doppler –ve, flow downstream by contrast injection Perforating veins diameter range from 3-25 mm (10.5+/-0.8) CYA Gr.: more Child-Pugh Class and more history of previous bleeding

slide.title: EUS-guided GVs: Coil vs Glue
slide.text:
EUS-guided GVs: Coil vs Glue Romero-Castro R, et al. Gastrointest Endosc 2013;78:711-721 Over all obliteration: 29/30: (one case-technical difficulty due to complex anatomy) Coil Gr.: 10/11-90.9% (14 sessions) vs CYA Gr.: 19/19-100% (29 sessions) 9/11 (81.8%) one session 10/19 (52.6%) one session 1/11 (9.1%) two sessions 8/19 (42.1%) two sessions 1/11 (9.1%) three sessions 1/19 (5.3%) three sessions 2/11 (18.2%) additional with CYA All obtained hemostasis and no recurrent Adverse event: overall 12/30 (40%) Coil Gr.: 1/9 (9.1%, 95% CI 7.9%-26.1%) vs CYA Gr.: 11/19* (57.9%, 35.7%-80.1%) p<0.01
Coil: 1 symptom-esophageal bleeding CYA: 2 symptom-fever, chest pain without embolism 9 asymptomatic pulmonary embolism (CT) * Including asymptomatic pulmonary embolism Hospital stay: Coil 6.0+/-2.4 D vs CYA 17.3+/-2.7 D, p=0.007 Cost per procedure: more expensive in Coil

slide.notes: Binmoeeler postulated coil will provide a scaffold for glue adherence
slide.notesNormalized: binmoeeler postulated coil will provide a scaffold for glue adherence
slide.notesHtml: Binmoeeler postulated coil will provide a scaffold for glue adherence
slide.text:
EUS-guided GVs: Coil plus Glue Authors study period Design Cases success no.coil vol.CYA F/U(Day) Obliteration Adverse event rate ml pain bleeding embolism
Bhat YM 2009-2015 Retro 152 GFV 151(99%) 1.4 (1-4) 2 (0.5-6) 436 (30-2043) 93 (93%) 3% 3% 1% 7(5%) active bleed 105 (69%) recent bleeding 40(26%) primary prophylaxis 96%
Binmoeller 2009-2011 Retro 30 GFV# 100% 1.4/varix 96% 2 active bleed (single session) (transesophageal approach) 14 recent bleed
# not good candidate for TIPSS Bhat YM, et al. GIE 2016;83:1164-72 Binmoeller KF, et al. GIE 2011;74:1019-25. “Coil can provide a scaffold for glue adherence* to decrease risk of migration” Hall PSJ , et al. Clin Endosc 2017;50:138-142

slide.title: EUS-guided GVs: Coil plus Sclerosant
slide.text: EUS-guided GVs: Coil plus Sclerosant Irisawa A. APDW 2015 Deploy coil till blocked variceal blood flow (confirmed by contrast varicealopgrphy) Injected sclerosant (ethanolamine oleate) Into varix including feeders 6 patients was performed with 100% success with no minor/major complication

slide.title: EUS-guided creation of an Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt
slide.titleNormalized: eus-guided creation of an intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
slide.text:
Figure 3 Stent located between hepatic and portal vein on necropsy.
Schulman AR, et al.Gastrointestinal endoscopy. 2017;85:243-247. EUS-guided creation of an Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt Buscaglia JM. A Gastrointest Endosc. 2009;69(4):941–947

slide.title: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management
slide.titleNormalized: eus for portal hypertension and varix management
slide.text: EUS for portal hypertension and varix management In summary: Recently, EUS has played role in case of unsecured EG variceal bleeding, recurrent bleeding in aspect of detecting deep collateral pathway-perforating veins (afferent), targeting with glue/coil deployment and confirming vessel obliteration as well. Furthermore, more trial in PPG measure and Intrahepatic portosystemic shunt may be bright future in clinical practice.
